The audit identified significant deficiencies in internal control, including a material weakness in SEC's financial reporting process, significant deficiencies in the design or operation of internal control over compliance with laws and regulations, and control deficiencies in SEC's period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures. The audit also identified information security weaknesses that could adversely affect decisions by SEC management based on inaccurate information.

The US Postal Service has a large workforce, with over 765,000 employees, including craft employees, management employees, and support employees. The Service has a commitment to providing equal employment opportunities to all employees and strives to create a diverse workforce. The Postal Service contracted with Aguirre International to review its diversity development program and evaluate its effectiveness in promoting diversity and inclusion.

<summary>
The US Department of Defense (DOD) defines a Military Working Dog (MWD) as any canine bred, procured, or acquired to support military operations. MWDs are removed from service when they can no longer perform their duties due to medical or behavior problems, and are adopted by former handlers or other eligible individuals. The DOD uses three systems to track information related to MWDs, including their removal from service, and the Army Veterinary Service provides medical care for MWDs through its Public Health Command Regions and Activities. The U.S. War Dogs Association provides assistance with privately provided veterinary care for adopted MWDs, and individuals with access to DOD medical care may also purchase care for their adopted MWDs at military installations.
</summary>

<summary>The Comanche program is a low-altitude reconnaissance and attack helicopter designed to replace the Army's aging OH-58 Kiowa helicopters. The program was established in 1983 and has experienced significant delays and cost overruns. The Army's restructuring of the program in 1994 included reducing the number of aircraft to be produced and extending the development phase by three years. The program's uncertainties in software development and aircraft maintainability increase the risk that the aircraft will not perform successfully. The Comanche will be the most computerized, software-intensive Army helicopter ever built, with over 2.7 million lines of code. Software development problems still exist with the Ada compilation system, and delays in software development and testing are occurring. The flight control system software verification testing is also being delayed, and the contractor team's plan to complete these tests prior to first flight may not be feasible. Configuration management is another area of concern, as the part of configuration management used to report software problems and changes among the contractor team and subcontractors has shortcomings that put software development at risk. The Army's goal of achieving lower operating and support costs and wartime availability goals is at risk due to key maintainability requirements such as direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation may not be achievable.</summary>

The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with food assistance, and the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) regulates the program. The program has several options and waivers that allow states to modify their eligibility determination process, reporting requirements, and benefit levels.

<summary>
The Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is responsible for administering various programs related to housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues. In 2000, HUD proposed a budget of $28 billion for new discretionary budget authority, which represents a 9% increase from the previous year. The budget includes 19 new initiatives and programs that were not funded in 1999, but some of these programs may have been funded in prior years. HUD is seeking to initiate and oversee new contracts for its Section 8 housing assistance program, which includes both project-based and tenant-based components. The budget justification for Section 8 does not provide sufficient information on the basis for contract renewal costs beyond 2000, and HUD's assumptions and source data for several years beyond 2000 are not provided. The CDBG Program provides grants to communities for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income people, and HUD's Integrated Disbursement and Information System (IDIS) is used to track grant information. However, IDIS is problematic and many states are hesitant to use it. HUD is proposing a new contract administration initiative for Section 8 contracts, which would relieve field staff of duties and allow them to concentrate on monitoring program effectiveness. HUD is also increasing its EZ Program, which includes a $45 million set-aside for Strategic Planning Communities that were not chosen for Round II EZ designation.
</summary>

The Military Health System operated by the Department of Defense (DOD) includes a dual health care mission of readiness and benefits, providing medical services and support to military personnel and their families, as well as retired service members and eligible beneficiaries. The replacement medical center being planned for the European theater will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for the EUCOM, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters of operation, and will be designed to accommodate contingency operations' medical needs. DOD officials have determined that the replacement medical center should be able to accommodate contingency operations' medical needs similar to those experienced in Fallujah, Iraq, during November 2004, and will be sized for peacetime operations, not for contingency operations.

The article discusses the exercise of discretion by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers in the apprehension and removal of aliens. ICE officers have discretion to exercise during various phases of the process, including initial encounters, charging, detention, and removal proceedings. However, the article notes that ICE guidance and procedures do not fully support officer decision-making in cases involving humanitarian issues and aliens who are not primary targets of ICE investigations. ICE has recently begun updating and revising training curricula for officers to provide critical information to inform their decision-making.

<summary>
The Ground Ambulance Services Payment System report was prepared by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) in response to a request from the Senate Finance Committee. The report examines the payment system for ground ambulance services provided to Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries. The report finds that the payment system is complex and varies by service area, with urban, rural, and super-rural areas having different payment rates. The median cost per transport for providers in the GAO's sample was $429 in 2010, with a range of $224 to $2,204. The report also finds that providers' costs per transport vary significantly, with level of volunteer staff hours, percentage of Medicare transports that are BLS, percentage of Medicare transports that are super-rural, and level of community tax support being the most important factors. The report concludes that the payment system does not provide adequate incentives for providers to control costs, and that the variability in costs per transport is not well understood. The report makes recommendations for improving the payment system, including the use of a national fee schedule and the consideration of provider characteristics when setting payment rates.
</summary>

<summary>The document provides information on the management of SRC I ammunition by the US Department of Defense (DOD). The Supply Chain Integration office is responsible for leading the development of DOD policies regarding SRC I ammunition. The Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force are the main stakeholders in the management of SRC I ammunition. The military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition. The Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number but plans to revise its guidance. The military services have maintained accountability of SRC I ammunition at 11 sampled locations, but there are gaps in some service-level guidance and procedures. The Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force conduct physical inventories of SRC I ammunition at required frequencies to ensure accountability.</summary>

The Social Security Administration (SSA) has a strict disclosure policy regarding personal information, including Social Security numbers, due to the sensitive nature of the information. SSA's policy is designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals while permitting the exchange of records necessary for administrative and program responsibilities. The policy requires SSA officials to consider several factors before disclosing personal information to law enforcement agencies, including the nature of the alleged criminal activity, the requested information, and the agency making the request. SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and the disclosure policies of most federal agencies, and it allows for disclosure only under certain conditions. The Commissioner of SSA has ad hoc authority to disclose information in exceptional cases approved on a case-by-case basis.

The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) establishes a national policy to minimize present and future threats to human health and the environment by regulating the management of hazardous waste. RCRA governs the management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal, including identification and listing of hazardous waste, treatment standards, land disposal restrictions, and permitting requirements. The land disposal restrictions and treatment standards are costly and complex, as they require parties to treat waste to stringent standards, even for low-risk contaminated media. Compliance with these requirements can drive parties to use less aggressive cleanup methods, such as leaving contaminated soil in place, and can increase cleanup costs and delays. Obtaining a RCRA permit can also be expensive and time-consuming, with estimates ranging from $80,000 to $1 million for a landfill and 5-6 years for a simple treatment unit. EPA and state cleanup managers have identified these requirements as creating disincentives for industry to clean up contaminated sites, as they can increase costs and time.

The Medicare program has dedicated funding for program integrity activities, including audits, medical review, secondary payer, and benefit integrity. From fiscal year 1997 to fiscal year 2005, CMS generally increased the amount of funding for each of its five program integrity activities, with provider education receiving the largest percentage increase. CMS has not fully assessed whether MIP funds are appropriately allocated within the audit, medical review, benefit integrity, and provider education activities, and does not have a means to compare quantitative data or qualitative information on the relative effectiveness of MIP activities.

<summary>
The performance of passenger and checked baggage screeners at airports has been a concern since 1978, with screeners failing to detect 13% of threatening objects in tests conducted by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in 1978, 20% in tests conducted in the late 1990s, and 45% in covert tests conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) in 2001. The TSA was established in 2001 in response to the 9/11 terrorist attacks and given responsibility for securing all modes of transportation, including aviation. TSA has faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training for screeners and in measuring and enhancing screener performance. TSA has taken steps to enhance the training of screeners and Screening Supervisors, including updating the basic screener training program and deploying a new dual-function (passenger and checked baggage) basic training curriculum. TSA has also provided FSDs with the flexibility to deliver basic screener training using local instructors. However, some FSDs have identified a need for more training in specific areas, including leadership, communication, and supervision. TSA has arranged for leadership training for screening supervisors through the Department of Agriculture Graduate School and has developed leadership and technical training courses for screening supervisors. Despite these efforts, TSA has faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training and in measuring and enhancing screener performance.
</summary>

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) operates a network of 25 call centers across the country to handle tax-related inquiries and issues from taxpayers. However, IRS lacks a long-term goal for the level of service it provides, which makes it difficult to strategically plan and manage call center performance. Without a clear goal, IRS relies on annual funding requests and workload assumptions to determine the staffing levels needed to meet projected call volumes. The Government Performance and Results Act requires federal agencies to develop strategic plans that include multiyear goals and the resources needed to achieve them. IRS is considering adopting measures used by other organizations to establish long-term goals for its call centers.

IRS faces challenges in recruiting, training, and retaining customer service representatives, including difficulties in finding suitable applicants and providing adequate resources for training. The standard training curriculum provided by all call sites includes periods of classroom instruction and on-the-job training, but there is a lack of refresher training for representatives after they receive initial training.

<summary>
Ginnie Mae is a government agency that operates as a unit of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). It was created in 1968 to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the nation's housing markets. Ginnie Mae provides guarantees to investors by pooling mortgages from various federal agencies, such as the Federal Housing Administration (FHA), the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), and the Rural Housing Service (RHS). These guarantees allow investors to receive timely payments of principal and interest on securities, regardless of whether the borrower makes mortgage payments or the issuer experiences financial difficulties. Ginnie Mae does not buy or sell loans or issue mortgage-backed securities (MBS) directly. Instead, it provides guarantees to issuers, who pool mortgages into MBS and sell them to investors. Ginnie Mae's original MBS program, Ginnie Mae I, requires that all pools contain similar types of mortgages with similar maturities and interest rates. The Ginnie Mae II MBS program permits pools to contain loans with more heterogeneous loans, such as adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs). Ginnie Mae's Multiclass Securities Program includes products such as REMICs and Platinum Securities, which allow investors to tailor the prepayment and interest rate risks associated with MBS to their investment goals. Ginnie Mae faces competition from other secondary market entities, such as the Federal Home Loan Banks, Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac, but it continues to finance the majority of government-backed loans. Despite this competition, Ginnie Mae's market volume has remained relatively stable over the years, and it continues to play a crucial role in the housing market.
</summary>

The above text is a report on the audit of the Defense Finance and Accounting Service's (DFAS) closed account adjustments. The report found that DOD had made $615 million in illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments in fiscal year 2000, and $1.9 billion in fiscal year 2001. DOD has reversed and corrected $592 million of these adjustments, and plans to complete the remaining $119 million by September 2004. The report also found that DFAS's contract reconciliation system and other controls were not in place to ensure that adjustments to closed appropriation accounts were proper, resulting in illegal adjustments. DOD officials agreed to reverse and correct the illegal adjustments, and have implemented new controls to prevent similar errors in the future. The report noted that while closed account adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002 totaled about $200 million, or 80% less than the previous year, $253,212 of illegal closed account adjustments had been processed from October 1, 2001, through March 31, 2002.

The Internet has grown significantly since its inception, and the US government played a crucial role in its development. In the 1990s, the US government supported the implementation of the domain name system (DNS), which is responsible for translating domain names into IP addresses. The DNS relies on a set of functions called the domain name system (DNS) to ensure uniqueness, and the US government supported the implementation of the DNS through a contract with the Department of Defense. In 1997, the US government issued a directive to transition the technical management of the DNS to the private sector, and the Department of Commerce (DOC) was tasked with implementing this transition. The DOC entered into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) to guide the transition. ICANN is a non-profit organization responsible for coordinating the global Internet's systems of Internet Protocol (IP) address allocation, autonomous system number allocation, root server management, and DNS securities. The MOU tasks ICANN with increasing competition, improving the stability and security of the DNS, and representing the functional and geographic diversity of the Internet. ICANN has made significant progress in increasing competition by allowing multiple companies to register domain names, but progress has been slow in improving the stability and security of the DNS. The DOC and ICANN have also faced challenges in implementing the at-large membership process, which was intended to provide broad representation of the Internet community on the ICANN Board. Despite these challenges, the DOC and ICANN have made significant progress in transitioning the technical management of the DNS to the private sector.

The federal government has held Indian tribes' funds since 1820, and the General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for the division of Indian tribal lands into allotments. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period of trust management indefinitely. The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and the Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) are responsible for managing Indian trust funds and assets. OST has implemented several trust fund management reforms, including the Trust Funds Accounting System and the Trust Beneficiary Call Center. BIA and OST are also responsible for developing centralized systems for managing land title records and leasing activities, as well as managing and tracking probates for Indian lands.

<summary>
The Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program was established to electronically share patient health data between the Departments of Veterans Affairs (VA) and Defense (DOD). In 2002, VA and DOD revised their strategy to achieve a two-way exchange of health information between their health information systems. The departments developed the CHDR initiative, which aims to create an electronic interface between their data repositories for the new systems. VA and DOD have implemented the Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) application, which exchanges data between VA's VistA system and DOD's CHCS system. The departments have also implemented the Laboratory Data Sharing Interface (LDSI), which enables the two departments to share laboratory resources. VA and DOD continue to work towards achieving a virtual medical record based on the two-way exchange of computable data between their health information systems.
</summary>

<summary>
The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) describes the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability of the taxpayer. IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, which include the scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management of an audit. The audit workpapers provide documentation on the scope of the audit and the diligence with which it was completed. IRS requires group managers to ensure the quality of the audits, leaving much discretion on the frequency and nature of their reviews during an audit. The IRM does not specifically require that all supervisory reviews be documented in the workpapers, although generally accepted government auditing standards do require such documentation. We found limited documentation of supervisory review in the audit workpapers, which raises questions about whether supervisory review is controlling audit quality as intended. Proposed changes to the IRM's sections on examination of returns require documentation of management involvement in the audit process. IRS is currently drafting changes to the IRM relating to workpapers, which will require documentation of managerial involvement.
</summary>

<summary>
The ATA program was established in 1983 to enhance the antiterrorism skills of friendly countries by providing training and equipment. DS/T/ATA is responsible for providing training and equipment to counterterrorism efforts, and S/CT provides policy guidance. However, there are weaknesses and inconsistencies in the needs assessments and program reviews, and the assessments do not consistently provide a basis for targeting program assistance. Only two of the assessments prioritized the recommendations, and the information included in the assessments was not consistent. DS/T/ATA did not systematically use the assessments to create annual country assistance plans, and some officials stated that they did not find the assessments useful. S/CT has mechanisms to coordinate the ATA program with other U.S. government international counterterrorism training assistance, but there is a lack of sustainability in the program. State did not have measurable performance goals and outcomes related to the mandated objectives for ATA prior to fiscal year 2003, but has recently made some progress to address the deficiency. DS/T/ATA appointed a Sustainment Manager in November 2006 to coordinate with other officials to enhance the sustainability of the program.
</summary>

The text provides an overview of the bankruptcy process for large financial companies in the United States. It explains that these companies can be reorganized or liquidated under bankruptcy laws, and that the bankruptcy process involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the U.S. Trustee Program, and the Federal Judicial Center. The text also highlights the importance of the automatic stay, which preserves assets and prevents creditors from taking company assets in payment of debts before a case is resolved, and the safe harbor provisions, which allow certain financial contracts to continue to be exercised even if the company is in bankruptcy. Finally, the text notes that the resolution of failed financial companies is subject to different national frameworks and may involve complex international, legal, and operational challenges.

The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations. The industry is facing threats to its cybersecurity, including unintentional threats such as natural disasters and defective equipment, and intentional threats such as hacking and terrorism, which can have serious consequences for the grid's reliability and security.

The federal government faces a high risk of mission failure due to skill gaps within the workforce. These gaps impede the government's ability to effectively serve the public and achieve results. The government's hiring process is not always effective in bringing in qualified candidates, and the current classification system is not well-suited to address the highly skilled and specialized nature of the federal workforce. Agencies need to improve their performance management systems to effectively evaluate and address poor performance.

<summary>
The cost of the Global War on Terror (GWOT) is difficult to estimate due to the ongoing nature of the conflict and the various funding sources used by the Department of Defense (DOD). In 2004 and 2005, DOD received approximately $52.4 billion and $62.1 billion, respectively, in supplemental appropriations for GWOT military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses. However, the military services also received additional funds through their annual appropriations, which were intended to support GWOT but were not specifically designated for that purpose. DOD and the military services have limited visibility over these funds, and there are no reporting requirements to track how they are used. The gaps between reported obligations and supplemental appropriations for GWOT military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses varied by service, with the Army and Air Force using transfer authorities to cover some of the gaps.
</summary>

The US government intervened in the financial crisis of 2007-2008 by providing capital to banks, buying toxic assets, and establishing programs to help struggling homeowners. The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was created to stabilize the financial system, and $426 billion was allocated to various programs. Despite the initial cost estimates of $341 billion, the program ended up costing $105 billion due to the successful stabilization of the financial system and the repayment of funds by banks.

The Federal Meat Inspection Act, the Poultry Products Inspection Act, and the Egg Products Inspection Act fall under the jurisdiction of the US Department of Agriculture (USDA). These acts extend to the safety of meat, poultry, and egg products, while the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Public Health Service Act fall under the jurisdiction of the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and cover the safety of food, drugs, and cosmetics.

The Federal Acquisition Service (FAS) manages the Multiple Award Contract (MAC) program, which provides a mechanism for federal agencies to purchase goods and services. The General Services Administration (GSA) is responsible for establishing and managing the MAS program, which is the largest interagency contracting vehicle. The GWAC program is another interagency contracting vehicle that provides a pre-competed vehicle for federal agencies to purchase technology products and services. The Enterprise Software Initiative (ESI) is a government-wide contracting vehicle for software licenses and related services. The Federal Procurement Data System-Next Generation (FPDS-NG) is the primary database for tracking federal procurement data, but it has been criticized for inaccuracies and unreliability. The Senior Procurement Executives (SPEs) from various federal agencies have expressed concerns about the lack of transparency and data availability on interagency and enterprisewide contracts. To address these concerns, the Office of Federal Procurement (OFPP) has initiated a survey to update the 2006 data collection initiative to identify the universe of MACs and enterprisewide contracts in use and assess their utility for maximizing procurement resources across agencies. OFPP is also assessing the feasibility of establishing and maintaining a centralized database to provide sufficient information on GWACs, MACs, and enterprisewide contracts for contracting officers to use to conduct market research and make informed decisions on the availability of using existing contracts to meet agencies' requirements.

<summary>
The source document discusses the investments made in IT by various organizations, including the federal government, to improve public services and organizational performance. The document highlights the failures of IT projects in the past, such as the Office of Personnel Management's Retirement Systems Modernization program, which was canceled after spending $231 million. 18F and USDS are two programs established to address these challenges and improve digital services in the federal government. 18F is an office within the Technology Transformation Service within GSA that provides custom application solutions, products, and platforms, and helps agencies with digital service delivery. USDS is a program that selects private sector experts to partner with government agencies to improve digital services. The document mentions that 18F has provided various development and consulting services to agencies, including custom software solutions, website design and development, and application programming interfaces. 18F has also helped agencies with digital service team candidate qualification reviews. The document concludes that 18F and USDS have provided satisfactory services to agencies.
</summary>

The baby boom generation's age will progress to the point where they will start to move from traditional working ages to retirement ages. By 2029, the aged dependency ratio will rise as there will be fewer workers to support each retiree. The number of older workers will grow substantially over the next two decades, with an increasing proportion in white-collar occupations. Labor force participation rates of older women are expected to increase, with a growth in participation rate to 61% by 2015. The labor force participation rates of males over age 55 are expected to increase, with a growth in participation rate to 69% by 2015. Older workers will become a larger percentage of all workers, with an expected increase from 13% to 20% by 2015. Between 2000 and 2008, the number and percentage of workers over age 55 will increase in all major occupational categories.

<summary>
The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was established in 1986 and allows certain nationals of participating countries to travel to the United States without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. To qualify for the VWP, countries must meet certain requirements, including providing reciprocal visa-free travel privileges to U.S. citizens, issuing machine-readable passports, and sharing information with the United States on citizens and nationals who may pose a threat to U.S. security. In 2008, the U.S. government implemented the Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) to assess passengers' eligibility for VWP travel before they board a U.S.-bound carrier. ESTA requires applicants to provide biographical information and responses to eligibility questions, and DHS evaluates the applications and notifies applicants of any disqualifications. The number of ESTA applications submitted increased from approximately 180,000 per month in 2008 to over 1.15 million per month in 2010, and DHS approved over 99% of the applications. DHS has taken steps to minimize the burden associated with ESTA's use, such as reducing the requirement for biographical information to be provided every 2 years and exercising the right to fine carriers for non-compliance with the ESTA requirement.
</summary>

The text describes the federal and state laws and policies regarding the permanency planning process for foster children, including the goals of reunifying families, terminating parental rights, and finding permanent placements for children. The text highlights the challenges of improving the permanency planning process, such as coordinating efforts among different agencies and stakeholders, and the importance of evaluating the impact of initiatives to ensure their effectiveness.

The Federal Agency Spending Transparency Act of 2016 requires federal agencies to report on their spending data to the USASpending.gov website. The Act expands on previous transparency legislation by requiring agencies to provide more detailed information on their spending, including financial assistance awards and procurement data. To help agencies meet these requirements, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has issued policy guidance and technical guidance, including a data standardization scheme and a broker for submitting spending data. However, agencies are facing challenges in implementing the Act, including issues with internal controls over financial reporting, proper use of accounting practices, and IT security and controls. Twenty-two of the 24 CFO Act agencies have issued annual financial reports for fiscal year 2016, but many have identified material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in their internal control over financial reporting. Nine of the 22 IGs reported issues or challenges related to accounting and financial management, and 14 of the 20 IGs reported issues or challenges related to internal controls over financial reporting. Additionally, 18 of the 22 auditors reported material weaknesses and significant deficiencies related to IT security and controls. These challenges increase the risk that agencies may not be able to provide complete, timely, and accurate spending data by May 2017.

<summary>
The Office of the Special Counsel (OSC) contracted with Management Support Services, Inc. (MPRI) for an organizational assessment without following proper contracting procedures. OSC did not obtain competition among Schedule vendors, and the justification for a sole-source order was inadequate. The contracting officer's representative (COR) designated by ARC did not have the necessary training or authority to perform contracting duties. Two OSC officials, the Special Assistant and Deputy Special Counsel, acted as CORs without proper training or delegation. ARC did not adequately document the reasonableness of MPRI's price, and the contracting officer's representative designated by ARC did not have the authority to perform contracting duties. The statement of work for the consultant hired by OSC on March 17, 2004, was consistent with OPM criteria for appropriate uses of expert and consultant appointments.
</summary>

The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) relies heavily on information technology (IT) to provide benefits and services to veterans. VA's IT infrastructure includes approximately 240 systems, 314,000 desktop computers, and 30,000 laptops, and supports the department's mission to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of veterans. However, some of VA's systems are old and in need of modernization or replacement, including two systems that are over 50 years old. VA has identified legacy systems that are over 50 years old and plans to retire them in 2017 and 2018. The department is also working to improve access to benefits and services through the use of improved technology and to eliminate the disability claims backlog by fully implementing an electronic claims process. VA has requested approximately $4.3 billion for IT in fiscal year 2017, including funds for new systems development, maintaining existing systems, and payroll and administration. The department's CIO has initiated a transformation strategy to focus on stabilizing and streamlining processes, mitigating weaknesses highlighted in GAO assessments, and improving outcomes by institutionalizing a new set of IT management capabilities. VA has also identified interoperability as a high-risk area and has taken steps to improve the sharing of health information between VA and DOD.

The Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) is the primary agency responsible for administering the Medicare program. HCFA faces significant challenges in managing the program, including a large and complex claims processing system, a lack of specialized expertise, and the loss of experienced staff. The agency is also struggling to implement recent reforms, such as the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, which introduce new health plan options and payment reforms. Despite these challenges, HCFA is focused on meeting important deadlines and pressures, but other critical functions may be receiving inadequate attention.

<summary>
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is primarily funded by the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, fuel, and other aviation-related activities. The administration has proposed changes to the funding structure to better align costs with revenues, including establishing direct user charges for commercial aviation and substantially increasing fuel taxes for general aviation. The proposal also calls for an advisory board to make recommendations on fee setting and limited authority for FAA to use debt financing. The current funding structure has successfully funded a growing FAA budget, and excise tax revenues are projected to increase substantially at current rates. However, some factors that drive tax revenues, such as ticket prices, are not well linked to FAA's workload and costs, raising concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency. The proposal to fund AIP through equal fuel taxes on all aircraft operators is intended to address equity concerns, but the distribution of the funding burden among user groups may not be fair. Commercial aviation users currently pay for a large share of benefits that come from capital spending at general aviation airports, and some portion of these benefits may accrue to commercial aviation users. The proposal to establish equal tax rates for commercial and general aviation operators was made to achieve fairness and simplicity. The administration's reauthorization proposal also calls for changing FAA's budget structure to align with its lines of business and proposed funding.
</summary>

The General Accounting Office (GAO) has been monitoring the Federal Telecommunications Service (FTS) program, which provides telecommunications services to federal agencies. GAO has identified five challenges that the General Services Administration (GSA) and the Integrated Management Office (IMC) face in finalizing the Networx acquisition program, including ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring and scheduling the Networx contracts, defining an acquisition strategy, and addressing lessons learned from previous acquisitions.

The Federal Student Aid (FSA) program manages and administers student financial assistance programs, including the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program and the Federal Family Education Loan Program. FSA has taken steps towards developing a strategic direction, but additional actions are needed to improve customer satisfaction, reduce unit costs, and enhance program integrity.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) received over $21,000,000 in Recovery Act funds in 2009 and 2010, which were used to fund grants for scientific research. The NIH used standard review processes to award these grants, and the grants varied in size, geographic distribution, and research methods. The NIH tracked the number of full-time equivalent (FTE) jobs supported by these grants using data reported by grantee institutions, which showed an increase from December 2009 to June 2011. The NIH also received information about other impacts of the Recovery Act funding, such as purchases of supplies and equipment, specialized services, and scientific training for healthcare professionals. Preliminary results from research projects funded by the Recovery Act could contribute to future scientific developments in preventive medicine and medical therapies.

<summary>
The source document describes transit-oriented development (TOD) as a compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhood located near public transportation. TOD aims to increase access to employment, educational, cultural, and other opportunities by promoting transportation options. The document highlights that local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, and metropolitan planning organizations play important roles in planning and implementing TOD. The Federal Transit Administration (FTA) provides funding for TOD research, coordinates with other agencies, and implements a TOD planning pilot program. FTA evaluates projects based on mobility improvements, environmental benefits, congestion relief, cost-effectiveness, economic development, and land use. The document identifies various factors that can support or hinder TOD, including market demand for real estate, available land for development, supportive local residents, efficient access to jobs and centers of activity, and challenges such as higher construction costs, reluctance from lenders, lengthy or discretionary local approval processes, and unsupportive local populations. The document concludes that understanding these factors is crucial for successful TOD implementation.
</summary>

<summary>
Since 1988, the Social Security Administration (SSA) has sent the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) to workers to review their earnings records and estimate retirement benefits. The current statement provides too much information, is too complex, and lacks effective layout and design, according to experts and focus group participants. SSA has revised the Commissioner's message for the 1997 PEBES to make it shorter and less complex, but the statement still contains too much information and is too complex. The statement lacks effective use of features such as bulleting and highlighting, and the structure is not clear at a glance. The public and benefit experts agree that the current statement contains too much information, but there is no clear consensus on how best to present benefit information. SSA has tested the public's reaction to receiving two separate documents, but the current PEBES still contains too much information and is too complex. SSA is considering a more extensive redesign of the PEBES for fiscal year 1999 mailings, but the redesign team is focusing on reducing printing costs without considering all of the factors that would ensure that the PEBES is a cost-effective document.
</summary>

The Social Security Administration (SSA) administers two programs that provide disability benefits to individuals who are unable to work due to medical conditions. The Disability Insurance (DI) program provides benefits based on an individual's past work history, while the Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program provides benefits to individuals with limited income and resources. Concurrent beneficiaries receive benefits from both programs and account for approximately 14% of SSA's disability population. SSA's guidance for administering the DI and SSI programs may contribute to the difficulty encountered by staff that specialize in one program but are required to collect information about both programs for concurrent beneficiaries.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has received $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds from the government, but it is not adequately tracking and reporting on the use of these funds. FEMA does not have mechanisms in place to collect and report on information from other agencies that are performing work on its behalf through mission assignments, resulting in incomplete and inaccurate reporting to the government.

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is responsible for integrating unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) into the national airspace. The FAA has authority to authorize all UAV operations in the national airspace, including military, public, and commercial entities. The FAA has a three-phase approach to UAV integration, including accommodation, integration, and evolution, with associated priorities for each phase. The FAA has issued a proposed rule for small UAVs and is working on a final rule for small UAV operations. The FAA faces critical steps to keeping the UAV integration process moving forward, including issuing a final rule for small UAVs and developing a detailed implementation plan to predict when full integration will occur and what resources will be needed.

<summary>
The document provides an overview of the Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP) in Afghanistan, which is a unique program that differs from other DoD programs due to its focus on development and reconstruction rather than neglected or damaged infrastructure. The program has evolved over time, with an increase in the number of complex projects and a higher cost. The program is managed by the Combined Joint Task Force-101 (CJTF-101), which is responsible for executing and managing the program. The program has faced challenges in providing adequate management and oversight due to insufficient personnel, leading to problems with project documentation, adherence to guidelines, and project tracking. The program requires additional personnel at brigade levels to perform essential functions, including project monitoring and oversight, consulting subject-matter experts, and conducting staff assistance visits. The lack of subject-matter experts poses a risk to the program's ability to identify and correct poor contractor performance, which could affect the cost, completion, and sustainability of CERP projects. The program's personnel have received little or no training on their duties and responsibilities, which has led to difficulties in contracting and oversight. The program's training is inadequate, and PPOs have less training but more authority under CERP, while warranted contracting officers have more experience and training before they can award contracts. Inadequate training has led to common mistakes in CERP contracts and project files, such as omitting key contract clauses or including clauses that are not appropriate. The lack of training affects the quality of oversight provided and can increase the risk of fraud.
</summary>

The text describes the results of a study on solar energy technologies supported by the US government. The study found that 65 initiatives across 6 federal agencies supported solar energy technologies, with a focus on photovoltaic and concentrated solar power technologies. The initiatives supported different types of technology advancement activities, including basic research, applied research, demonstration, and commercialization. The study also found that the initiatives overlapped in terms of technology advancement activities, types of technologies, and types of funding recipients, but this overlap does not necessarily lead to duplication of efforts.

<summary>
The Department of Defense (DOD) has inaccurately assessed the risk to military operations due to inadequate inventory management of chemical and biological protective equipment. DOD uses a multipurpose overboot, improved mask, and new gloves to address the issues. The military services have shortages of protective suits, gloves, and hoods, which will increase through 2007. DOD's current inventory management system is unreliable, and the Defense Logistics Agency and military services store war reserve inventories of chemical and biological protective suits and other equipment at various depots, warehouses, and storage facilities. The services cannot easily link inventory records, track, and locate defective suits, and have miscalculated the requirements and the number of suits available. The Army and Marine Corps reported significantly more gloves on hand than required and could transfer some to the Air Force to offset Air Force shortfalls. DOD's plan to buy fewer new suits is influenced by expiration of the suits and budgetary considerations. The services have shortages of one component of the ensemble, and critical shortages or opportunities for cross-service assistance tend to be obscured.
</summary>

Summary:

The article discusses the importance of program evaluations in the federal government, particularly in the 24 agencies governed by the Chief Financial Officers (CFO) Act. Evaluations are crucial in assessing program performance, identifying areas for improvement, and informing decision-making. However, the 2013 and 2017 surveys of federal managers revealed that many agencies lack access to recent evaluations, and managers often lack awareness of evaluations conducted by others. Despite this, managers who had access to evaluations reported that they contributed significantly to improving program management and understanding. Evaluations can also help allocate resources within programs, support budget requests, and measure complex or costly forms of performance. However, the process of influencing change through evaluation can be iterative and complex, requiring multiple studies to occur. To address this, federal agencies use various methods to disseminate evaluation findings to local decision-makers. Overall, the article highlights the need for improved coordination and collaboration in federal programs, as well as the importance of using evaluation evidence to inform decision-making.

The federal government has implemented the Rehabilitation Act to promote the employment of individuals with disabilities in the federal workforce. The Act requires federal agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities and to designate a senior-level official to be accountable for meeting the goals of the executive order. OPM has issued guidance to agencies on implementing the executive order and has developed a system for reporting on agencies' progress in implementing the order. Agencies are required to provide quarterly monitoring of the rate at which employees injured on the job successfully return to work. OPM has also developed mandatory training programs on the employment of people with disabilities for both human resources personnel and hiring managers.

The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is developing an automated land and mineral case processing system (ALMRS) to manage public lands and resources. The ALMRS system includes three components: ALMRS Initial Operating Capability (IOC), Geographic Coordinate Database (GCDB), and technology modernization and rehost of selected systems. BLM has been working on the ALMRS project since 1983 and has allocated $403 million for the project through 2002. Despite delays and cost overruns, BLM is still on track to complete the project by September 1996.

The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is responsible for verifying that nuclear materials are not diverted from peaceful use to nuclear weapons. The IAEA has been reviewing the nuclear activities of countries since 1970, and has implemented strengthened safeguards to detect clandestine nuclear programs. These measures include collecting and analyzing environmental samples, using measurement and surveillance systems, and conducting complementary access to verify the absence of undeclared nuclear material and activities. The IAEA has faced limitations in its ability to draw conclusions about undeclared nuclear activities, including limited access to sites and countries' failure to provide comprehensive information. Despite these challenges, the IAEA has successfully revealed previously undeclared nuclear activities in several countries, including Iran, South Korea, and Egypt. However, the IAEA recognizes that it cannot draw absolute conclusions about undeclared nuclear activities and that a determined country can still conceal such activities.

The public and private sectors face a high risk of disruption due to the Year 2000 problem, which could affect critical services such as telecommunications, banking, and defense. The US government is also at risk, with many of its computer systems containing two-digit years that will fail on January 1, 2000. The President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion has been established to address the issue, but progress has been slow. Agencies have not set priorities for fixing systems, and contingency planning has been inadequate. End-to-end testing has not been defined, and independent verification and validation of testing is needed. The government and private sectors must work together to address the Year 2000 problem to avoid widespread disruptions.

The Information Quality Act (IQA) of 2000 requires federal agencies to manage information to ensure its integrity, quality, and utility. In 2002, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) developed governmentwide guidelines for implementing IQA, which agencies were required to follow by October 2003. However, many independent agencies have not developed their own IQA guidelines, and some agencies have not made their guidelines easily accessible on their websites. OMB has not provided specific guidance on how agencies should provide access to IQA information on their websites, and agency IQA officials have reported that access to online IQA information is not always user-friendly.

<summary>
The source document discusses the impact of mutual funds on deposits in the banking industry.
Both mutual funds and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and invest them in the economy.
Mutual funds do not make loans, but they invest in securities, primarily bonds and stocks.
The funds' investments become a source of new finance to the economy, and the securities markets play a crucial role in this process.
The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds has had a significant impact on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy.
The deposit-to-GDP ratio has been pushed down by a number of factors, including a downsizing of the savings-institution industry, a decline in loans at commercial banks, and a shift by banks into greater use of nondeposit funding sources.
The Federal Reserve and the Securities Industry Association (SIA) agree that mutual funds have attracted significant amounts of money that otherwise might have been placed in bank deposits.
The total net flows into mutual funds from all sources during 1990 through 1994 were $1,067 billion.
Using the ratio of deposits to GDP as a benchmark, the total impact of mutual funds on deposits may have been sizable but probably less than $700 billion.
The movement of money from bank deposits to mutual funds should have little if any effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds available to the economy.
</summary>

The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 requires specific activities related to bioterrorism preparedness and response, including improving coordination and planning among federal, state, and local officials, developing technical and reporting standards, and increasing funding for public health preparedness efforts. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has funded over $2.7 billion for public health preparedness efforts through grants administered by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA). HHS has also established the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology to develop a strategic plan for implementing interoperable health information technology in the public and private health care sectors. CDC's Public Health Information Network (PHIN) is a national initiative to implement a multi-organizational business and technical architecture for public health information systems, including integrating existing systems and coordinating with other federal agencies, state and local government agencies, and the private health care sector. PHIN is also intended to improve public health systems and networks and provide a means for exchanging data with other federal agencies, state and local government agencies, and the private health care sector.

<summary>
The survey of large sponsors of defined benefit (DB) pension plans reveals changes in benefit formulas, plan freezes, and automatic enrollment for DC plans. Most respondents reported no changes to their DB plans, but 81% modified benefit formulas, and 58% froze some plans. Automatic enrollment for DC plans is increasing, with 72% of respondents offering it for non-bargaining employees and 46% for collective-bargaining employees. Health benefits are also important, with 80% offering retiree health benefits to some current retirees and 46% offering no benefits to active employees hired after a certain date. Respondents reported a total retiree health liability of $68 billion, representing 40% of the $174 billion in DB liabilities. Most respondents were not planning to make significant changes to their benefit offerings before 2012, despite recent legislation and accounting rule changes.
</summary>

The text describes the process of refugee resettlement in the United States, highlighting the various agencies and stakeholders involved. The Refugee Act of 1980 established a systematic and permanent procedure for admitting refugees, and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Department of State, and the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) are responsible for different aspects of the process. Voluntary agencies, such as the nine national voluntary agencies, play a crucial role in resettling refugees, proposing the number of refugees to be resettled in each community, and providing services to help them become self-sufficient. However, there are challenges in ensuring that local stakeholders are consulted and involved in the resettlement process, which can lead to friction between refugees and the local community. Despite these challenges, communities can benefit socially and economically from refugee resettlement, as refugees bring new perspectives, customs, and skills, and can help stimulate economic development.

The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established NFIP as an alternative to providing direct assistance after floods. NFIP provides government-guaranteed flood insurance to homeowners and businesses, and the program's inception has led to the development of various policies and regulations. Despite the program's successes, there are still several challenges that need to be addressed, such as charging premium rates that reflect actual risks, limiting costs to taxpayers, and encouraging private market participation. FEMA has taken various actions to mitigate these challenges, including introducing new rating options and increasing premium rates. However, these actions have not fully addressed the issues, and further reforms are needed to ensure the program's solvency and reduce taxpayer exposure. Expanding participation in NFIP and improving mitigation efforts could help reduce costs and ensure that losses from flood damage do not become the responsibility of taxpayers.

<summary>
The 287(g) program is a joint effort between ICE and state and local law enforcement agencies to enhance public safety and security by addressing criminal activity by removable aliens. The program allows state and local officers to perform immigration functions, including arresting, detaining, and processing aliens for removal. ICE has developed three models for state and local law enforcement participation in the program, including the "jail model," "task force model," and "joint model." The program has grown rapidly in recent years, and ICE has received funding to support it. However, the program lacks management controls, such as specific objectives, defined use of authority, and consistent communication of responsibilities. ICE has not consistently articulated how participating agencies are to use their 287(g) authority, nor has it described the nature and extent of ICE supervision over these agencies' implementation of the program. The program's MOAs are not consistent with statements by ICE officials regarding the use of 287(g) authority, and some MOAs do not mention when the authority is to be used. ICE has not defined the responsibilities required of ICE agents directing and supervising local officers under the 287(g) program.
</summary>

<summary>
The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) oversees mutual funds through its Office of Compliance Inspections and Examinations (OCIE), Division of Investment Management, and Division of Enforcement. SEC regulates mutual funds through the Investment Company Act of 1940, the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, the Securities Act of 1933, and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC's Division of Enforcement investigates and prosecutes violations of securities laws related to mutual funds. SEC's OCIE conducts regular examinations of mutual funds to ensure compliance with federal securities laws and regulations. SEC has revised its examination approach to focus on targeted examinations of higher-risk funds and advisers, and to monitor larger funds on a continuous basis. SEC has also established the Office of Risk Assessment to assist in carrying out its overall oversight responsibilities. SEC officials have stated that the agency's traditional focus on routine examinations had limitations and that the agency is placing a higher priority on sweep and cause examinations and a lower priority on routine examinations. SEC is also providing more continuous and in-depth oversight of the largest mutual funds and forming examiner teams dedicated to monitoring the largest and most complex groups of affiliated advisers and funds.
</summary>

<summary>
The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) is an independent federal corporation that provides electricity to customers in the Tennessee Valley region. TVA is governed by a board of directors and has a strategic plan to reduce its debt from $26 billion to $22 billion by 2023. To achieve this goal, TVA plans to increase revenue through rate increases, limit the growth of operating expenses, and reduce capital expenditures. TVA's board sets the agency's goals and policies, approves the CEO's appointment, and develops long-range plans. TVA's most recent strategic plan covers fiscal years 2014-2018 and outlines the agency's "strategic imperatives," including maintaining low rates, living within its means, and managing its assets to meet reliability expectations. TVA has a 10-year long-range financial plan to determine the amount of funds available for capital investment. Utilities deal with uncertainty in demand forecasts by producing a range of forecasts based on demographic and economic factors and maintaining excess generating capacity as reserves.
</summary>

The First City Bancorporation of Texas, Inc. experienced financial difficulties in the late 1980s and early 1990s, leading to a recapitalization agreement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) in 1988. Despite this assistance, the banks continued to experience financial difficulties, leading to the closure of the Houston and Dallas banks in 1992. The FDIC declared the Houston bank insolvent and appointed receiver, while the Texas Banking Commissioner closed the Dallas bank due to imminent insolvency. The FDIC exercised its statutory authority to issue immediately payable cross-guarantee demands on the remaining 18 First City banks. The failure of the Houston and Dallas banks resulted in a loss of $625 million for First City, and the FDIC received $100 million in payments from the bank's assets. The events leading to the failure of the First City banks were the result of a combination of factors, including poor risk management, inadequate capital, and deteriorating economic conditions in Texas.

The Single Audit Act of 1984 was passed to improve the federal government's oversight of grants given to state and local governments. The act established a single audit concept to replace multiple grant audits with a single audit of an entity's entire financial system. The Single Audit Act Amendments of 1996 refined the act and expanded uniform audit requirements to cover all federal grant recipients. The act assigned responsibilities to various entities, including OMB, federal agencies, and their respective Offices of Inspector General (OIG). The auditor of the grant recipient is required to perform the audit in accordance with GAGAS. A single audit consists of an audit and opinions on the fair presentation of financial statements and the Schedule of Expenditures of Federal Awards (SEFA), as well as testing of internal control and compliance with legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements. The PCIE study found that approximately 49% of single audits reviewed were unacceptable or had limited reliability, with deficiencies including lack of evidence of internal control testing and compliance testing for most or all compliance requirements.

The Medicare program was created in 1965 and has since used health insurers to process and pay claims. However, the program's contracting structure has limited competition and innovation, leading to dwindling numbers of insurers willing to serve as Medicare contractors. The Social Security Act and implementing regulations restrict the program's ability to contract with entities other than health insurers, limiting the program's ability to use competitive contracting to improve performance. The program could benefit from various contracting reforms, such as allowing Medicare to directly choose contractors on a competitive basis and allowing contractors to specialize in specific functions. The program also faces challenges in terminating contractors, as the Social Security Act limits the agency's ability to terminate intermediaries and carriers. Implementing performance-based contracting will require significant time and care to effectively promote better performance and accountability, and eliminating contractors' ability to unilaterally terminate contracts will help address challenges the agency faces in finding replacement contractors on short notice.

The Department of Defense (DOD) has been focusing on reducing its logistics costs by outsourcing non-core activities to private sector companies. The DOD Office of the Secretary (OSD) requested the Defense Business Board (DBB) to identify areas where private sector companies could provide support services more efficiently and at lower costs. The DBB conducted two studies and estimated that DOD could save $6 billion to $12 billion annually by outsourcing logistics activities. However, the Pentagon's Office of Audit and Evaluation (PA&E) has questioned the accuracy of these estimates, suggesting that they are overstated by $1 billion to $2 billion.

The Federal Government has been reducing its workforce and streamlining operations to improve efficiency. In 1993, both Congress and the administration agreed that federal employment levels should be cut. The Government Performance and Results Act of 1993 requires agencies to develop strategic plans, measure their performance, and submit annual reports on program performance. Five components were selected for review: HUD's Office of Housing, GSA's Public Buildings Service (PBS), DOI's Bureau of Reclamation (BOR), NASA's Human Space Flight Program, and OPM's Investigations Service. The downsizing of these components ranged from 2% to 100%. To maintain performance, components took steps such as refocusing their missions, reengineering work processes, and building and maintaining employee skills. Limited customer survey data was available, but customers generally supported the view that performance had been maintained. Officials and employees believed that efforts to maintain performance had been successful, but some expressed concern about maintaining performance with additional downsizing. The lessons learned by components included the importance of open communication and soliciting employee input in the planning process.

The National Research Program (NRP) is an IRS initiative designed to obtain voluntary compliance information from taxpayers by measuring reporting compliance. NRP aims to obtain accurate information but minimize burden on taxpayers. IRS implemented NRP by training auditors, classifying returns, and conducting audits to verify information.

The Bureau is planning to conduct the 2010 Census using a three-legged stool approach, which includes modernizing the Master Address File (MAF) and the Topologically Integrated Geospatial Data (TIGER) system, launching the American Community Survey (ACS), and expanding the use of technology such as handheld mobile computing devices. The Bureau's three-legged stool strategy is aligned with three of its four key goals for the 2010 Census, but reducing operational risk is less clear. The Bureau faces challenges in securing congressional approval for its proposed approach and in providing comprehensive and transparent information to support its plans. The Bureau's planning for the 2010 Census has improved compared to the 2000 Census, but certain information gaps remain, including complete life cycle cost estimates and resolution of methodological and other questions related to ACS. The Bureau is taking a significant risk by pinning the success of its reform efforts largely on a survey that may not be an adequate replacement for the long form. The Bureau's efforts to ensure that ACS data will serve as a satisfactory replacement for long-form data are not yet complete, and several issues remain critical to the reliability of small geographic area ACS data. The implementation of each leg of the Bureau's three-legged stool is dependent on the other, and the success of the entire approach depends on the Bureau's ability to address these challenges and provide comprehensive and transparent information to support its plans.

According to the text, the use of electronic prescribing technology can improve the quality of care received by patients and reduce healthcare costs. The text also highlights the importance of protecting the privacy of health information, as mandated by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act.

<summary>
The Medical Home Support Service (MHSS) of the US Department of Defense (DOD) provides medical readiness for active-duty military personnel. The MHSS requires medical support to prepare for and during combat and maintain the health of active-duty personnel during peacetime. The main mission of the MHSS is to provide medical readiness, which requires medical support to active-duty military personnel. The MHSS needs psychiatrists and clinical psychologists to treat mental conditions. The MHSS has enough psychiatrists and clinical psychologists to meet its current and upcoming medical readiness requirements. The MHSS has a surplus of psychiatrists and clinical psychologists. The Psychopharmacology Demonstration Project (PDP) was established to train military psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medication for mental illness.
</summary>

<summary>
The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a complex and ambitious space observatory under development by NASA, with a planned launch in 2018. JWST is designed to observe the universe in infrared light, with unprecedented sensitivity and resolution, and will study the formation of the first stars and galaxies in the early universe. The telescope consists of several elements and major subsystems, including the Optical Telescope Element (OTE), the Integrated Science Instrument Module (ISIM), and the spacecraft. JWST faces significant technical challenges and risks, including the development of a cryogenic cooler to cool the infrared light detector to about 6.7 Kelvin, and the integration and testing of the various elements and subsystems. The project has experienced significant delays and cost overruns, and the baseline funding does not reflect the most probable cost with adequate reserves in each year of project execution, resulting in an unexecutable project. NASA has replanned the project and placed a cap on the formulation and development costs, but the project remains at risk of technical challenges and schedule delays. The project has used schedule reserve to address various technical problems that have arisen, including issues with the ISIM and OTE elements, and workmanship issues with the cryogenic harnesses that connect to the mirrors. Various spacecraft challenges have also used up schedule reserve.
</summary>

<summary>
The source document discusses the security of chemical facilities in the United States, particularly the risk they pose to public health and safety in the event of a terrorist attack. The document highlights that while there are regulations in place to secure other critical infrastructure sectors, such as water and transportation, chemical facilities are not subject to the same level of security requirements. The document notes that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is developing a plan to protect the chemical sector, which will include a framework for reducing the overall vulnerability of the sector in partnership with the industry and state and local authorities. DHS has initiated actions to identify critical assets, prioritize facilities, and develop and implement protective programs. The document also mentions that industry associations have been active in promoting security among member companies, but the extent of participation in the industry's voluntary initiatives is unclear. The document concludes that DHS lacks specific authority to address security concerns at chemical facilities and that legislation is needed to give the federal government greater authority over chemical facility security.
</summary>

<summary>
The Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) requires federal agencies to protect personal information in systems of records. The Privacy Act of 1974 and the E-Government Act of 2002 address the protection of personal privacy in federal agencies. The Privacy Act defines a "system of records" as a group of records maintained by an agency that contains personal information about an individual. The E-Government Act requires agencies to conduct privacy impact assessments (PIAs) before developing or procuring information technology that collects, maintains, or disseminates personal information. The Chief Privacy Officer at the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is responsible for ensuring that personal privacy is protected in DHS programs. DHS has developed a data mining tool called ADVISE, which is being considered for several different applications within the department. However, DHS did not conduct a privacy impact assessment (PIA) for ADVISE, which could have identified privacy risks and mitigated them. The TSA's passenger prescreening program, Secure Flight, has faced privacy problems, including the collection of personal information from commercial sources without fully informing the public. TSA has added privacy experts to its development teams to address privacy issues as they arise. DHS is planning to spend about $9 million on acquiring personal information from information resellers in fiscal year 2005. The agency's practices for handling this information do not always reflect the Fair Information Practices, and there is a lack of agency policies that specifically address the use of personal information from resellers.
</summary>

Social Security is a federal program that provides financial assistance to millions of Americans, including retirees, disabled workers, and dependents. The program was created in 1935 and has since expanded to include benefits for survivors, spouses, and children. Despite its popularity, the program faces financial challenges due to demographic changes and declining birth rates, which could result in benefit reductions unless reforms are implemented.

The TARP program was established in 2008 to stabilize the US financial system during the financial crisis. The program provided capital injections, asset guarantees, and other forms of support to banks and other financial institutions. As of 2014, Treasury had recovered most of its investments and had a remaining investment balance of $625 million, with a estimated lifetime income of $16.1 billion.

The US electricity sector is facing a number of environmental regulations that are aimed at reducing air pollution, water resources, and solid waste. These regulations include the Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, and Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, among others. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed four key regulations that will affect the electricity industry, including the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards (MATS) regulation, which requires coal-fired power plants to reduce mercury emissions by over 75%. The EPA has also proposed regulations to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants, which could have significant impacts on the industry's ability to reliably deliver electricity. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) and the Department of Energy (DOE) are also involved in monitoring the industry's progress in implementing these regulations. Reliability challenges and potential increases in electricity prices are among the concerns being monitored by RTO officials and industry stakeholders. The EPA, FERC, and DOE have taken initial steps to monitor industry progress in responding to the regulations, but more effort may be needed as new and pending regulations are finalized.

<summary>
The USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA) has not consistently determined the eligibility of estates for farm program payments, leading to potential improper payments totaling millions of dollars. FSA has not conducted required annual determinations for many estates, and when determinations are made, they are often incomplete or inaccurate. The agency has also not implemented management controls to verify the eligibility of individuals receiving program payments or to detect improper payments to deceased individuals. As a result, FSA has paid millions of dollars in farm program payments to deceased individuals, including $400,000 to an Illinois farming operation in the name of a deceased individual. The agency has agreed with GAO's recommendations to improve its oversight of farm program payments, including conducting all required annual determinations and implementing management controls to verify eligibility and detect improper payments.
</summary>

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has been experiencing difficulties in modernizing its air traffic control (ATC) system, which is critical to the safety of air travel. The FAA's modernization program has faced delays, cost overruns, and performance shortfalls. The agency has fielded some new equipment, but interim projects have been added to sustain and enhance current automation equipment. The FAA has encountered delays and cost increases in two key components of its modernization effort, the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) and the Standard Terminal Automation Replacement System (STARS). The agency has been slow to develop a complete and enforced systems architecture, which has led to compatibility problems among its existing and future programs. The FAA lacks reliable cost-estimating processes and cost-accounting practices, which has led to poor investment decisions. The agency's cultural culture has contributed to its acquisition problems, and it needs to implement comprehensive cultural change initiatives to address these issues.
